metadata.title: Aerobic and anaerobic biosynthesis of nano-selenium for remediation of mercury contaminated soil

Highlights  A new promising bioremediation technology for soil Hg was reported.  Hg was stably immobilized as HgSe by bacteriogenic nano-Se0.  Aerobically and anaerobically produced nano-Se0 can be applied to
surface and subsurface soils.
 Biogenic nano-Se0 is better than chemically synthesized nano-Se0 for
Hg remediation
 Sodium dodecyl sulfonate can increase Hg remediation using
biogenic nano-Se0.

23 Running title: Biosynthesis of nano-Se0 and mercury remediation

sections.heading: 25 ABSTRACT
sections.text:
26 Selenium (Se) nanoparticles are often synthesized by anaerobes. However, anaerobic 27 bacteria cannot be directly applied for bioremediation of contaminated top soil which 28 is generally aerobic. In this study, a selenite-reducing bacterium, Citrobacter freundii 29 Y9, demonstrated high selenite reducing power and produced elemental nano30 selenium nanoparticles (nano-Se0) under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions. The 31 biogenic nano-Se0 converted 45.8-57.1% and 39.1-48.6% of elemental mercury (Hg0) 32 in the contaminated soil to insoluble mercuric selenide (HgSe) under anaerobic and 33 aerobic conditions, respectively. Addition of sodium dodecyl sulfonate enhanced Hg0 34 remediation, probably owing to the release of intracellular nano-Se0 from the bacterial 35 cells for Hg fixation. The reaction product after remediation was identified as non36 reactive HgSe that was formed by amalgamation of nano-Se0 and Hg0. Biosynthesis of 37 nano-Se0 both aerobically and anaerobically therefore provides a versatile and cost38 effective remediation approach for Hg0-contaminated surface and subsurface soils, 39 where the redox potential often changes dramatically.
40 41 Keywords: Bioremediation; selenium; mercury; metal immobilization; selenium 42 nanoparticles
4

sections.heading: 44 1. Introduction
sections.text:
45 Mercury (Hg) is a naturally occurring non-essential highly toxic metal in the Earth’s 46 crust, and it is widely used in many industries such as the extraction of gold from 47 ores, production of NaOH and chlorine in the chlor-alkali industry, and manufacture 48 of compact fluorescent lamps, cosmetics, insecticides and herbicides (Boening, 2000). 49 In some cases, improper use has led to extensive mercury pollution of soil. For 50 example, mercury concentrations in the soil around a chlor-alkali plant in the 51 Netherlands reached up to 1150 mg kg-1 (Bernaus et al., 2006). Mercury emissions 52 were also detected in surrounding soils and sealed waste ponds near a chlor-alkali 53 factory (Southworth et al., 2004).
54 55 Mercury speciation in contaminated soil can be classified into water soluble, 56 elemental, exchangeable, strongly-bound, organic, sulfide and residual fractions. 57 Normally, elemental mercury comprises a small proportion of the total mercury in soil 58 whereas in mercury or gold mining regions and in chlor-alkali plant soil, elemental 59 mercury may account for a much larger part of the total mercury. In the Idrija mercury 60 mine region, Slovenia, HgS is the predominant mercury fraction, followed by Hg0 61 (Kocman et al., 2004). Elemental mercury accounted for ~95% of the total mercury in 62 soils heavily contaminated with mercury in Venezuela (García-Sánchez et al., 2006). 63 Soil beneath and adjacent to the Pavlodar Chemical Plant in Kazakhstan was also 64 contaminated by mercury, and ~88-98% of the total mercury can be present as 65 elemental mercury (Neculita et al., 2005). Therefore, there is an urgent need to treat
5
66 elemental mercury-contaminated soil, particularly that caused by the industries 67 mentioned above.
68 69 Selenium (Se) is in the same group as sulfur in the Periodic Table, and has an 70 extremely high affinity for mercury with △G0= -38.1 kJ mol-1, which is higher than 71 that for sulfur (Ho et al., 2015). A large amount of work has been carried out on 72 detection of mercury and selenium in fish, marine mammals and humans. The molar 73 ratio of mercury to selenium in such samples was approximately 1, which suggested 74 detoxification of mercury into less toxic mercuric selenide (HgSe) (Southworth et al., 75 2000; Squadrone et al, 2015). Selenium nanoparticles have already been shown to be 76 effective for mercury removal from off gases, and unstabilized amorphous nano-Se0 77 showed a strong mercury capture capacity of 188 mg g-1 dry weight (Johnson et al., 78 2008; Lee et al., 2009). Biogenic red amorphous nano-Se0 has also been applied to 79 sequester mercury vapour released from mercury-contaminated museum specimens, 80 the historic mercuric chloride treatment to preserve specimens leading to mercury 81 volatilization (Fellowes et al., 2011). Nano-Se0 therefore appears to be a promising 82 mercury-trapping agent for cleanup, disposal, recycling and packaging applications 83 (Ralston, 2008).
84 85 Most of these examples of mercury removal by selenium are concerned with mercury 86 vapour in the atmosphere. However, this technique can also be applied to the aquatic 87 environment. For example, Pseudomonas fluorescens could reduce SeO32- and Hg2+
6
88 into elemental forms, the interaction between these two elements resulting in the 89 formation of Hg-Se complexes within the cells with a Hg:Se molar ratio close to 1 90 (Yang et al., 2011). Bioreduced Hg0 by a strain of Shewanella putrefaciens was 91 captured as HgSe by extracellular biogenic amorphous selenium nanospheres (Jiang et 92 al., 2012). However, no studies have been carried out which have tested the capacity 93 of biogenic nano-Se0 to immobilize mercury in soil.
94 95 Bioremediation of contaminated soil can be limited by the redox potential and the 96 performance of the remediating bacteria in aerobic and anaerobic conditions. Surface 97 soil layers are usually aerobic while subsurface soil layers may be anoxic, which 98 means that both aerobic and anaerobic processes may be required. In addition, the soil 99 redox potential during bioremediation may change drastically as bacterial cultures and 100 substrates are applied. This may increase the cost, complexity and performance of 101 bioremediation. Therefore, an ability for microbes to produce nano-Se0 both 102 aerobically and anaerobically may be relevant for the bioremediation of mercury103 contaminated soils. Using versatile facultative bacteria to remediate soils with quite 104 different redox potentials could be simpler and more effective.
105 106 In the present study, the performance of the facultative anaerobe Citrobacter freundii 107 Y9, which can produce amorphous nano-Se0 under anaerobic and aerobic conditions, 108 in sequestering elemental mercury in soil was evaluated. Sequential soil extraction of 109 mercury was carried out to determine changes in mercury speciation, and the reaction
7
110 products were characterized by scanning electron microscopy with energy-dispersive 111 X-ray spectrometry (SEM-EDS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron 112 microscopy (TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).
8
114 2. Materials and methods 115 2.1. Bacteriogenic nano-Se0 116 Citrobacter freundii Y9, isolated from sludge from an anaerobic sulfate-reducing 117 bioreactor in Urumqi, China was used in this study, and the sequence has been 118 submitted to Gene Bank (number KF781347). The growth medium contained the 119 following components: 1.0 g K2HPO4, 0.1 g MgCl2, 0.2% yeast extract, 10 mM 120 sodium citrate in 1 L Milli-Q water. The medium was adjusted to pH 7.0-7.2 using 0.1 121 M HCl, and sterilized in a vertical heating pressure stream (LDZX-75KBS, Shanghai, 122 China). The bacteria were cultured at 260C in 500 ml serum bottles in a Whitley 123 DG250 anaerobic workstation (Don Whitley Scientific, West Yorkshire, England), 124 and aerobically in 250 ml flasks with constant shaking at 150 rpm.
125 126 To measure the selenite reduction activity of C. freundii Y9, late logarithmic phase 127 cells (5%) were inoculated into fresh medium containing 1 mM sodium selenite, 128 added from a sterile 500 mM sodium selenite stock solution. At appropriate time 129 intervals, samples were collected and filtered using 0.22 μm hydrophilic 130 polyestersulfone membranes. Selenite in the filtrates was analyzed by LC-HGAFS 131 (Liquid Chromatography-Hydride Generation Atomic Fluorescence Spectrometry) 132 (Jitian, Beijing, China). Determination of the number of viable cells (colony-forming 133 units, CFU) was conducted as follows to measure the growth of bacteria (Tugarova et 134 al, 2014). A series of consecutive ten-fold dilutions of bacterial suspensions were 135 made using sterile physiological saline (0.87% NaCl); 200 μl of the corresponding
9
136 diluted samples were then spread on solid nutrient broth medium and cultured for 4-5 137 d at 260C. Abiotic nano-Se0 was prepared using L-ascorbic acid as a reductant to 138 reduce H2SeO3, polyvinyl alcohol (PVA, 0.05%) was used as a soft template. The 139 abiotic nano-Se0 was centrifuged at 10,000×g for 10 min and then re-suspended in 140 PVA solution (0.05%). Biogenic and abiotic selenium were characterized by SEM141 EDS and XRD.
142 143 2.2. Elemental mercury immobilization in soil 144 Biogenic and abiotic nano-Se0 were used to capture mercury in contaminated soil 145 under aerobic and anaerobic conditions. Soil was collected from farmland near 146 Urumqi, China, sterilized in a vertical heating pressure stream (LDZX-75KBS, 147 Shanghai, China), and air-dried, sieved (1 mm), and sterilized again under UV 148 light irradiation for 2 h. Liquid mercury was added to the soil directly which was then 149 aged for two months. The mercury immobilization tests were performed in centrifuge 150 tubes which contained 25 g of elemental mercury contaminated soil and 25 ml 151 medium containing 4 mM elemental selenium. When biogenic nano-Se0 was used to 152 treat mercury contaminated soil, one group contained 1% sodium dodecyl sulfate 153 (SDS) to lyse the bacteria and release intracellular Se0. The original concentration of 154 soil mercury was analyzed using a mercury analyzer (Lumex RP91C, Saint 155 Petersburg, Russia). After one week, the different mercury fractions in the soil 156 samples were analyzed. A control without addition of nano-Se0 was also treated in the 157 same way. The elemental selenium in the medium or in the PVA suspensions was
10
158 centrifuged at 12,000×g for 10 min and then the Se-free supernatant was added to the 159 control. Anaerobic and aerobic immobilization were performed inside a Whitley 160 DG250 anaerobic workstation or in a fume hood, respectively.
161 162 Sequential extraction procedures were used to evaluate mercury speciation in the soil, 163 according to previously published methods (Biester and Scholz, 1996; Shi et al., 164 2005). Mercury compounds were classified into the following fractions: F1: total 165 mercury; F2: elemental mercury; F3: water-soluble and exchangeable mercury; F4: 166 mercury bound to organic matter; and F5: residual mercury. Total mercury (F1) was 167 analyzed using a mercury analyzer (Lumex RP91C, Saint Petersburg, Russia) and this 168 value was labelled THg1. For elemental mercury (F2), the soil was heated at 1800C 169 for 2 h in a muffle furnace to separate out the elemental mercury. After this treatment, 170 the total mercury left in the soil was again analyzed and this value was labelled THg2. 171 The remaining soil was set aside for the following treatment. For water-soluble 172 mercury and exchangeable mercury (F3), 20 ml Milli-Q water (18 MΩcm-1) was 173 added to 2 g soil from the F2 treatment and shaken for 2 h. The mixture was then 174 centrifuged for 20 min at 12,000×g. Another 20 ml of 1 M CaCl2 (pH=5) was added 175 to the soil and shaken for 2 h. The mixture was then centrifuged for 20 min at 12,000 176 ×g, then air dried. The total mercury left in the soil was again analyzed and this value 177 was labelled THg3. The remaining soil was set aside for the following treatment. For 178 mercury bound to organic matter (F4), 20 ml of 0.2 M NaOH was added to the treated 179 soil from F3 and shaken for 2 h. The mixture was centrifuged as described previously,
11
180 and then 20 ml CH3COOH 4% (v/v) was added to the soil and shaken for 2 h. The 181 mixture was then centrifuged as previously described, air dried and the total mercury 182 left in the soil analyzed as above, which was labelled THg4. According to the 183 following formulae, the concentrations of the different mercury fractions in the soil 184 were obtained: F1= THg1; F2= THg1-THg2; F3= THg2-THg3; F4= THg3-THg4; 185 F5= THg4.
186 187 2.3. SEM-EDS, XRD, TEM and XPS analyses 188 The synthesized selenium particles and the soil after the experiments were analyzed 189 by SEM-EDS. These samples were first freeze-dried in a vacuum freeze dryer 190 (Labconco, Kansas, USA) then coated with gold with a sputter coater (Emitech K575, 191 Kent, UK). Samples were examined using a scanning electron microscope (Zeiss 192 Super 55VP, Oberkochen, Germany). Elemental analysis was carried out using 193 energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (Bruker XFlash 5010, Berlin, Germany).
194 195 Samples for XRD were first freeze-dried, and then XRD spectra were obtained using 196 an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8, Karlsruhe, Germany) with a Cu anode (40 kV 197 and 30 mA) and scanning from 5 to 800 2θ.
198 199 In order to further characterize biogenic selenium particles, TEM was conducted as 200 follows (Zhang and Frankenberger, 2006). Cells were harvested by centrifugation 201 (10,000×g, 10 min) and fixed with 2.5% para-formaldehyde + 2.5% glutaraldehyde
12
202 in 0.1 M cacodylate buffer (pH 7.2) and post-fixed with 1% OsO4 + 0.15% ruthenium 203 red in 0.1 M cacodylate buffer. After washing three times with Milli-Q water, cells 204 were dehydrated in graded acetone solutions (30, 50, 70, 90 and 100% for 15 min 205 each time) and then embedded in Epon-Araldite. Blocks were sectioned using a 206 Reichert Supernova Microtome (Leica AG, Wien, Austria) using a diamond knife 207 producing sections approximately 80 nm in thickness. The samples were observed 208 using a JEM-1200EX electron microscope (JEOL, Tokyo, Japan).
209 210 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was carried out on powders using a Thermo 211 ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) 212 using an Al Ka monochromatized source. Surface charging effects were corrected 213 with a C 1s peak at 284.6 eV as a reference. Curve fitting and decomposition were 214 achieved assuming Gaussian-Lorentzian fitting following Shirly background 215 subtraction.
216 217 2.4. Reagents 218 All the chemicals and reagents used in this study were of analytical grade. SDS, 219 H2SeO3 and Na2SeO3 were supplied by Guang Fu (Tianjin, China). Selenite was 220 prepared as a 500 mM stock solution in Milli-Q water (18 MΩcm-1) and sterilized 221 using 0.22 μm hydrophilic polyestersulfone membrane filters (Shanghai, China). 222 Liquid mercury was obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent (Shanghai, China). 223 PVA was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Ltd. L-ascorbic acid was supplied by Yong
13
224 Sheng (Tianjin, China).
225 226 2.5. Statistical analysis 227 The size of selenium particles was calculated using Image-Pro Plus 6.0 based on SEM 228 spectra. All experiments were carried out in triplicate; error bars on figures show 229 standard deviations’.
14
231 3. Results and discussion 232 3.1. Bacteriogenic nano-Se0 233 C. freundii Y9 could reduce selenite to elemental selenium particles, which was 234 evident by the colour of the medium changing to red/orange, under both aerobic and 235 anaerobic treatments. There was no colour change and no change of selenite 236 concentration in the abiotic control which demonstrated that it was the presence of 237 growing bacteria that led to the reduction of selenite. After inoculation, bacterial 238 growth was concomitant with the process of reduction. C. freundii Y9 showed more 239 tolerance to selenite under anaerobic conditions and over 24 h, the medium turned red, 240 and there was a rapid decrease in selenite concentration with complete removal after 5 241 d (Fig. 1). However, under aerobic conditions the medium turned a weaker red after 242 24 h with the efficiency of selenite reduction being 27% after 5 d incubation, the 243 concentration of selenite remaining stable after this time (Fig. 1). Anaerobic selenite 244 reduction was rapid and more pronounced than in aerobic conditions. In an anaerobic 245 mode of respiration, selenite can be used as an electron acceptor in dissimilatory 246 reduction (Macy et al., 1989), or be reduced and incorporated into organic compounds 247 in assimilatory reduction (Lortie et al., 1992; Gadd, 1993). However, the mechanisms 248 under aerobic conditions are not clearly understood.
249 250 SEM of C. freundii Y9 showed that particles were present inside the cells after 251 exposure to 1 mM selenite; such particles were also detected extracellularly (Fig. 2b, 252 c, d). EDS spectra of the particles confirmed the presence of selenium with

253 characteristic selenium absorption peaks at 1.37 and 11.22 keV (Fig. 2e). The 254 calculated diameter of selenium particles ranged from 200-800 nm, with the average 255 diameter being 580±109 nm. XRD patterns showed a broad peak at 2θ values from 256 250 to 300, which indicated that the selenium particles formed were amorphous in 257 nature (Fig. 2f). TEM showed that electron-dense particles were present inside the 258 cells near the cytoplasmic membrane after incubation with 1 mM selenite (Fig. 2g, h). 259 The biogenic selenium was deposited inside the cells or extracellularly and during cell 260 lysis the elemental selenium could be released into the extracellular medium.
261 262 C. freundii is commonly found in soil, freshwater and marine habitats. Although, 263 selenate reduction has been reported in C. freundii (Zhang et al., 2008), there is less 264 work on selenite reduction, and the electron transfer system is different between 265 selenate and selenite reduction in this organism (Siddique et al., 2006). As selenate is 266 generally more toxic than selenite (Hockin and Gadd, 2003, 2006), it is perhaps better 267 to use selenite as an electron acceptor to obtain nano-Se0.
268 269 3.2. Abiotic nano-Se0 270 The mixture of PVA-stabilized selenium nanoparticles had a red/orange colour and 271 remained stable on prolonged incubation. SEM and EDS spectra confirmed the 272 presence of elemental nano-Se0 (Fig. 3). The diameters of these nano-Se0 particles 273 ranged from 10-90 nm with an average value of 71±16 nm. However, without PVA in 274 solution, a dark red precipitate of Se0 appeared. The XRD pattern of chemically-
16
275 reduced elemental selenium was the same as that for biogenic elemental selenium, 276 indicating that the elemental selenium formed here was also amorphous.
277 278 3.3. Elemental mercury immobilization in soil 279 The ability of biogenic and abiotic elemental amorphous nano-Se0 to immobilize Hg0 280 in soil was comparatively studied. The total mercury in the contaminated soil was 281 21.43±2.51 μg g dry weight-1 which is ~350-fold higher than values commonly 282 found. Elemental mercury was the primary fraction (17.63±2.10 μg g-1 dry weight) 283 which accounted for 78.2-84.6% of the total mercury, while 11.1-11.7% (2.46±0.28 284 μg g-1) of the mercury occurred in the insoluble residual mercury fraction. When 285 mercury-contaminated soil was supplied with nano-Se0, the total mercury decreased 286 only slightly, some possibly being volatilized or adhering to surfaces of the 287 bioreactor. However, the mercury speciation changed significantly, especially in the 288 elemental and residual fractions (Fig. 4). Under anaerobic conditions, Hg0 present in 289 the mercury-contaminated control decreased by 11.3% (1.99 μg g-1). However, there 290 was a 73.5% (12.96 μg g-1) and 63.5% (11.20 μg g-1) decrease in Hg0 when the soil 291 was supplied with biogenic Se0 + SDS and biogenic Se0, respectively. The SDS was 292 used in an attempt to release intracellular Se0 from the bacterial cells and therefore 293 enhance the reaction between Hg0 and Se0. For the abiotic Se0 treatment, 49.2% (8.68 294 μg g-1) of the Hg0 fraction decreased. Under aerobic conditions, Hg0 present in the 295 control decreased by 12.5% (2.67 μg g-1). However, there was a 65.8% (11.60 μg g-1) 296 and 61.25% (10.79 μg g-1) decrease in Hg0 when the soil was supplied with biogenic
17
297 Se0 + SDS and biogenic Se0, respectively. For the abiotic aerobic Se0 treatment, Hg0 298 decreased by 38.9% (6.87 μg g-1). Concomitant with the decrease in Hg0, the residual 299 mercury fraction was found to increase significantly. Under anaerobic conditions, 300 residual mercury in the mercury-contaminated control increased by 0.73 μg g-1. 301 However, there was a 10.79 μg g-1 and 8.80 μg g-1 increase in residual mercury when 302 the soil was supplied with biogenic Se0 + SDS and biogenic Se0, respectively. For the 303 abiotic Se0 treatment, residual mercury increased by 4.44 μg g-1. Under aerobic 304 conditions, residual mercury in the control increased by 0.85 μg g-1. However, there 305 was a 9.41 μg g-1 and 7.75 μg g-1 increase in residual mercury when the soil was 306 supplied with biogenic Se0 + SDS and biogenic Se0, respectively. For the abiotic 307 aerobic Se0 treatment, residual mercury was increased by 3.15 μg g-1. Thus, addition 308 of abiotic or bacterially-produced nano-Se0 to mercury-contaminated soil under 309 anaerobic and aerobic conditions led to a decrease in the proportion of Hg0 present, 310 and an increase in the insoluble residual Hg fraction.
311 312 The efficiency of abiotic nano-Se0 preparations was less than that for biogenic nano313 Se0 after SDS treatment which is surprising since the diameter of the abiotic nano-Se0 314 (10-90 nm) was much smaller than that of biogenic nano-Se0 (200-800 nm). In 315 general terms, selenium capture of mercury occurs by a gas-solid reaction where the 316 capacities and kinetics mainly depend on surface area: smaller particles have a larger 317 specific surface area (Johnson et al., 2008). However, the PVA template may have 318 blocked some elemental mercury access to elemental selenium which would inhibit
18
319 the reaction between selenium and mercury. Other workers have found similar results, 320 e.g. BSA-stabilized nano-Se0 had a lower sorption capacity than conventional 321 selenium powder despite a much smaller particle size (6-60 nm vs 10-200 µm) 322 (Johnson et al., 2008). Thus, biogenic nano-Se0 gave a better performance for Hg0 323 immobilization in soil.
324 325 3.4 Speciation of Hg immobilized in soil 326 According to the SEM-EDS of immobilization products (Fig. 5), the atomic ratio of 327 Hg:Se is close to 1 (Table 1), which revealed the formation of HgSe. XRD (Fig. 6) 328 also confirmed that mercury and selenium were in the form of HgSe (PDF#65-2892). 329 XPS analysis shows that binding energy of Hg 4f7/2 and Hg 4f5/2 was observed at 99.2 330 eV and 104.3 eV, respectively (Fig. 7), indicating that mercury could be present as 331 HgSe and HgO (Zylberajch-Antoine et al., 1991). Deconvolution of the high 332 resolution XPS spectra of selenium shows the presence of binding energy peaks of Se 333 3d5/2 at 53.8 eV and Se 3d3/2 at 54.5 eV, which is in good agreement with that 334 previously reported for HgSe (Wall et al., 1986). The binding energy values for Se0 at 335 Se 3d5/2 (54.7 eV) and Se 3d3/2 (55.2 eV) were in accordance with those reported in 336 the literature (Miyake et al., 1984). The XPS results confirmed immobilization of Hg0 337 by nano-Se0 as HgSe.
338 339 To date, many technologies have been examined for remediation of mercury340 contaminated soil, such as immobilization (stabilization or solidification) electro-
19
341 remediation, soil flushing and soil washing, vitrification, thermal desorption and 342 phytoremediation (Wang et al., 2012). Thermal treatment is the most widely used 343 method although the treated soil is unsuitable for reuse due to the destruction of 344 original soil properties (Yang et al., 2008), with some techniques also leading to 345 mercury release into the air (Wang et al., 2012). The work presented here has shown 346 that amorphous nano-Se0 is capable of capturing Hg0 in both surface and subsurface 347 soil, thereby reducing mobility due to the production of HgSe. HgS is the typical 348 residual form of mercury in soil, but HgSe also has a very low solubility (Ksp=10-58) 349 and is more stable than HgS (Björnberg et al., 1988). As well as this, the use of nano350 Se0 appears safer since HgSe is chemically inert and a much less toxic compound 351 compared to other forms of mercury and selenium. In addition, nano-Se0 is unharmful, 352 and the median lethal dose (LD50) for nano-Se0 is 6.7 g kg-1 in rats (Cummins and 353 Kimura, 1971). Therefore, immobilization of mercury with nano-Se0 may provide an 354 efficient means of soil remediation with no secondary pollution and no volatilization. 355 However, soil is a heterogeneous complex environment, and it is necessary to 356 consider the wider applicability of this technique across different soil types and 357 physico-chemical conditions as well as the stability of nano-Se0. Moreover, the effects 358 of different soil compositions and conditions on the reaction between nano-Se0 and 359 Hg0 also need to be taken into consideration.
360 361 4. Conclusions 362 This work is the first demonstration that amorphous nano-Se0 can be applied to
20
363 capture Hg0 in soil under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions. It is concluded that 364 C. freundii could be more easily and successfully applied for remediation of surface 365 and subsurface soils, where the redox potential often changes dramatically. The 366 experiments have revealed the formation of non-reactive HgSe by amalgamation of 367 elemental selenium and elemental mercury which provides a potential approach for 368 mercury immobilization in mercury-contaminated sites.
